qas.question: What is the abbreviation for licensed dietitians in the US?
Who do dietitians have to register with other than the American Dietetic Association in order to be recognized as such in the US?
Which specific term is unregulated but still oft associated with professionals when it comes to food and diets?
Which state has started to regulate the word "nutritionist"?
What are restaurants and food manufacturers required to follow in order to assist consumers looking to follow dietary guidelines?

context: In the US, dietitians are registered (RD) or licensed (<a0_0>LD<a0_0/>) with the <a1_0>Commission for Dietetic Registration<a1_0/> and the American Dietetic Association, and are only able to use the title "dietitian," as described by the business and professions codes of each respective state, when they have met specific educational and experiential prerequisites and passed a national registration or licensure examination, respectively. In California, registered dietitians must abide by the "Business and Professions Code of Section 2585-2586.8". Anyone may call themselves a <a2_0>nutritionist<a2_0/>, including unqualified dietitians, as this term is unregulated. Some states, such as the State of <a3_0>Florida<a3_0/>, have begun to include the title "nutritionist" in state licensure requirements. Most governments provide guidance on nutrition, and some also impose mandatory <a4_0>disclosure/labeling requirements<a4_0/> for processed food manufacturers and restaurants to assist consumers in complying with such guidance.
